newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Two S.Korean troops, two agents killed in clashes.
newsitem.headline: Two S.Korean troops, two agents killed in clashes.

text.p: Two South Korean soldiers and two North Korean infiltrators were killed on Sunday in two separate armed clashes in rugged east coast mountains, a defence ministry spokesman said.
In one shootout during the night, a Northern agent and a Southern soldier were killed, the spokesman said.
The other Northern infiltrator was killed in the later gunbattle at dawn and a South Korean soldier died while being rushed to a military hospital, he said.
An earlier ministry statement had said all four casualties occurred in the gunbattle at dawn.

The latest casualties brought to nine the number of North Koreans killed by Southern forces in a massive hunt for an estimated 26 communist agents who landed by submarine on Wednesday on a beach near the east coast city of Kangnung.
Eleven other agents were found shot dead, possibly killed by their colleagues, and one was captured alive.
A total of three Southern troops have now been reported killed in a deadly game of cat-and-mouse over mountain trails covered with thick vegetation.

A Southern paratrooper was killed on Saturday. According to some reports he was hit while dangling on a winch line from a helicopter that was lowering him to the ground. Another paratrooper was injured.

An army officer in Kangnung said one of the North Koreans killed on Sunday was wearing a Southern army uniform while the other was in civilian clothes. He said a rifle and a grenade were found at the scene.
A defence ministry official in Kangnung said South Korean naval ships began towing away the North Korean submarine. He declined to elaborate on details, including the destination.
Thousands of troops backed by helicopters have been engaged in a massive manhunt to end one of the deadlist operations from the enemy North since the early Cold War.
South and North Korea have been technically at war since their 1950-53 conflict ended only with an armistice agreement.

Details of the Northern infiltration remain confused, although the defence ministry believes that the agents included three elite saboteurs. These three may have been responsible for the execution-style killings of the 11 on Wednesday in a ruthless bid to improve their own survival chances.

Authorities trying to unravel the mystery of the mission -- which ran into serious trouble when the submarine grounded on a reef -- are relying on statements from the captured North Korean agent, who has changed his story several times.
The Hankook Ilbo daily on Sunday quoted agent Lee Kwang-soo as telling interrogators the team carried high explosives.
It said this suggested the mission could have been intended to stage a terrorist-style attack or destroy key facilities.
Lee was quoted as saying the explosives may have been thrown into the sea or hidden on land.

In an incident unrelated to the infiltration drama later on Sunday, a South Korean army private, armed with a rifle and dozens of rounds of ammunition, was involved in a confrontation with troops after deserting from his barracks near the inter-Korean border, a second defence ministry spokesman said.

The deserter fled into a nearby border area, which had been mined to prevent North Korean infiltrations, after opening fire at random and throwing two hand grenades into a kitchen and barracks at his unit, the spokesman said. Nine soldiers were wounded in the incident.
Several of the soldiers attacked by the deserter were wounded seriously and rushed to a miltiary hospital, he said.
